bibl.title: Letter from Fred W. Rankin to George A. Kellogg, April 20, 1942

div1.p: Rankin suggests corrections to the Cornwell painting of McDowell in surgery and states that he may not be able to attend the unveiling and make a speech.

div1.head: Letter from Fred W. Rankin to George A. Kellogg, April 20, 1942
div1.opener:
fwr-bab
COPY
WAR DEPARTMENT
Office of the Surgeon General
Washington
April 20, 1942 Mr. George A. Kellogg
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, New Jersey
COPY
Dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
Your letter of March 24 has not been answered more
promptly, simply because I have not had time to do it.
I am very happy over the black and white photograph you
sent.

I have talked the matter of the tumor over with
some of the surgeons here and I am still not quite satis-
fied with it. In the first place, the tumor sticks up
too high. In the second place, the patient is lying a
little on her right side. The tumor should be flattened
out a little more and come up to the ensiform cartilage.
The surgeons I have shown the picture to and discussed it
with have agreed with these criticisms, and while they are
not highly important points, I do believe they are worth-
while. There is something about the breast, the upper part
of which shows, that is not exactly correct, I think. It
may be shadow, but I am not quite satisfied with the appear-
ance and you ought to scrutinize it and talk it over with
one of your gynecological friends.

As to making a short speech at the unveiling of the
painting on Monday noon, June 8th, I shall be glad to do
so if it is possible. However, I am going to be compelled
to attend the House of Delegates at that time and it is
quite questionable if I shall be there. Nevertheless I
shall do my best to attend. Thanking you for your many
courtesies, I am

closer.signed:
Fred W. Rankin
Colonel, Medical Corp.
closer.seg: P.S. The tumor should shift a bit to the right side.
